A New Table of Constant Weight Codes
A. E. BROUWER, lAMES B. SHEARER, N. I. A. SLOANE, FELLOW, IEEE, AND WARREN D. SMITH

Joakim Ekberg
Geometries of Binary Constant Weight Codes

A New Table of Constant Weight Codes of Length
Greater than 28
D. H. Smith, L. A. Hughes and S. Perkins
Division of Mathematics and Statistics
University of Glamorgan, Pontypridd, CF37 1DL, Wales, UK
{dhsmith,lahughe1,sperkins}@glam.ac.uk
Submitted: Feb 3, 2006; Accepted: May 1, 2006; Published: May 12, 2006
Mathematics Subject Classification: 94B60


11111100000000000000000000000000 0
10000011111000000000000000000000 1
10000000000111110000000000000000 2
10000000000000001111100000000000 3
10000000000000000000011111000000 4  Cubes 0 to 4 share number 0
01000010000100001000010000100000 5
01000001000010000100001000010000 6
01000000100001000010000100001000 7
01000000010000100001000010000100 8  Cubes 5 to 8 share number 1
00100010000010000010000010000010 9
00100001000100000001000001001000 10
00100000100000100000110000010000 11
00100000010000010100000100100000 12 Cubes 9 to 12 share number 2
00010001000000010001000001000100 13




Reed Soloman
n=32 (29?)
k=25
d=5

weight of each is 6
block length n=q-1
message length k
distance n-k+1
Examples of non-trivial MDS maximum distance separable codes include Reed-Solomon codes.

Ahhh d = 10!!!!
So according to http://www.win.tue.nl/~aeb/codes/Andw.html
A(n,d,w) = A(30,10,6) = 25!!!
so there are 25 possible codewords with length 30 bits.
